Generation I.Red: In the distant past, it was somewhat stronger than the horribly weak descendants that exist today.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: In the distant past, it was somewhat stronger than the horribly weak descendants that exist today.
Generation I.Yellow: Famous for being very unreliable. It can be found swimming in seas, lakes, rivers and shallow puddles.
Generation I.Stadium: Whoever its opponent, and however horrible the attack it receives, all it does is Splash around.

Generation II.Gold: An underpowered, pathetic Pok é mon . It may jump high on rare occasions, but never more than seven feet .
Generation II.Silver: For no reason, it jumps and splashes about, making it easy for predators like Pidgeotto to catch it mid-jump.
Generation II.Crystal: This weak and pathetic Pok é mon gets easily pushed along rivers when there are strong currents.
Generation II.Stadium 2: An underpowered, pathetic Pok é mon . It may jump high on rare occasions, but never more than seven feet. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) For no reason, it jumps and splashes about, making it easy for predators like Pidgeotto to catch it mid-jump. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Magikarp is a pathetic excuse for a Pok é mon that is only capable of flopping and splashing. This behavior prompted scientists to undertake research into it.
Generation III.Sapphire: Magikarp is virtually useless in battle as it can only splash around. As a result, it is considered to be weak. However, it is actually a very hardy Pok é mon that can survive in any body of water no matter how polluted it is.
Generation III.Emerald: Its swimming muscles are weak, so it is easily washed away by currents. In places where water pools, you can see many Magikarp deposited there by the flow.
Generation III.FireRed: It is virtually worthless in terms of both power and speed. It is the most weak and pathetic Pok é mon in the world.
Generation III.LeafGreen: In the distant past, it was somewhat stronger than the horribly weak descendants that exist today.

Generation IV.Diamond: It is said to be the world's weakest Pokémon. No one knows why it has managed to survive.
Generation IV.Pearl: It is unable to swim against even slow-moving currents. It always splashes about for some reason.
Generation IV.Platinum: A Magikarp living for many years can leap a mountain using Splash. The move remains useless, though.
Generation IV.HeartGold: An underpowered, pathetic Pokémon. It may jump high on rare occasions, but usually not more than seven feet .
Generation IV.SoulSilver: For no reason, it jumps and splashes about, making it easy for predators like Pidgeotto to catch it mid-jump.

Generation V.Black: A Magikarp living for many years can leap a mountain using Splash. The move remains useless, though.
Generation V.White: A Magikarp living for many years can leap a mountain using Splash. The move remains useless, though.
Generation V.Black 2: A Magikarp living for many years can leap a mountain using Splash. The move remains useless, though.
Generation V.White 2: A Magikarp living for many years can leap a mountain using Splash. The move remains useless, though.

Generation VI.X: It is virtually worthless in terms of both power and speed. It is the most weak and pathetic Pokémon in the world.
Generation VI.Y: In the distant past, it was somewhat stronger than the horribly weak descendants that exist today.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Magikarp is a pathetic excuse for a Pokémon that is only capable of flopping and splashing. This behavior prompted scientists to undertake research into it.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Magikarp is virtually useless in battle as it can only splash around. As a result, it is considered to be weak. However, it is actually a very hardy Pokémon that can survive in any body of water no matter how polluted it is.

Generation VII.Sun: Although weak and helpless, this Pokémon is incredibly fertile. They exist in such multitudes, you'll soon grow tired of seeing them.
Generation VII.Moon: Its reckless leaps make it easy pickings for predators. On the bright side, many Pokémon enjoy longer life spans, thanks to Magikarp.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: In the distant past, they were fairly strong, but they have become gradually weaker over time.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: Thanks to their strong hold on life, dirty water doesn't bother them at all. They live in waters all over the world!
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Famous for being very unreliable. It can be found swimming in seas, lakes, rivers, and shallow puddles.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Famous for being very unreliable. It can be found swimming in seas, lakes, rivers, and shallow puddles.

Generation VIII.Sword: It is virtually worthless in terms of both power and speed. It is the most weak and pathetic Pokémon in the world.
Generation VIII.Shield: This weak and pathetic Pokémon gets easily pushed along rivers when there are strong currents.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It is said to be the world's weakest Pokémon. No one knows why it has managed to survive.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It is unable to swim against even slow-moving currents. It always splashes about for some reason.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: A feeble, pitiful imbecile of a Pokémon that is nonetheless very hardy. Unperturbed by turbid water, it can be found living in all sorts of places.

Generation IX.Scarlet: An underpowered, pathetic Pokémon. It may jump high on rare occasions but never more than seven feet.
Generation IX.Violet: In the distant past, it was somewhat stronger than the horribly weak descendants that exist today.
